messages: 3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (20:55): The spec is kind of hard to read if you're not trying to find full browser implimentation details.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:56): 3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32: See alternate style sheets

3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (20:57): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I do not understand.  I wasn't actually complaining about the spec, just responding to b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f / annevk2.
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (20:58): Validators happen, browser implimentors clearly need more help :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:58): It's still true and makes it easier to read
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (20:59): What's true?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:00): 3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32: Everything that's not false
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (21:00): 3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32: if you're actually coding javascript, though, you need implementation details to make sure your code works right
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:00): unless you're a constructivist, I suppose
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (21:00): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: hm, constructionism
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:00): 3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32: there is an 'author view' style sheet that hides some parts of the spec
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:01): 69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537: I have not noticed that.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:01): blinks
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:01): ChrisWilson? In #whatwg? What's the world coming to?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:02): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: What about things that cannot be proven, and hence are neither true nor false?
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:03): things that cannot be proven are neither true nor false?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:03): I think it depends on whether you believe in the law of the excluded middle
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:03): Nothing can be proven, not even your own existence.
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:03): I don't think so
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:04): lots of things that are either true or false cannot be /proven/
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:04): I'm lacking motivation to do the validation steps after basic nesting :/
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:04): for example, every historical fact
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:04): was replying mostly to a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:06): only cares about cares about real proof, like in maths, not about anything fuzzy like history :-p
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:07): I figure valadation works out to:  basic nesting, conditional nesting (including sequence / required elements), and value type enforcement.
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:07): Sounds pretty simple.  Still.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:07): and many people consider it axiomatic that everything is either true or false, in which case the things a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 asked about don't exist
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:07): I hate the word "maths".
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:08): (regardless of whether everything can be proved)
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:09): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: ah, but "things that cannot be proven" is what a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 asked about
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:10): 69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537: It is still possible that those things are either true or false
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:10): 69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537: It's just we can't prove it
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:10): 69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537: They are a subset of things, and if all things are either true or false, then the things in the subset are too
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:10): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: agreed
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:11): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: yes, surely
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:13): (I think most people will agree that "colorless green ideas sleep furiously" is neither true nor false, though)
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:15): 69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537: Did you just make that quote up?
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:16): 3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32: no, it's from Chomsky
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:16): only cares about proper stuff like maths, so he's not interested in sleeping ideas unless they're expressed in formal logic :-p
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:16): I still hate the word "maths".
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:17): What word would you prefer?
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:19): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: "math".
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (21:21): bloody americans
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:21): But mathematics is plural, so why should the abbreviation be singular?
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (21:21): (scare quotes implied)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:21): heads off
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:22): Does the "s" in "mathematics" actually imply plural?
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:23): I don't know what a mass noun is.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:24): It's like "kilogram"
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:24): LOL
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:24): A mass noun is uncoutable
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:24): *uncountable
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:24): it's like "water" or "sand"
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:24): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: So the "s" doesn't imply plural?
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:25): you don't have waters or sands, (except poetically)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:25): 3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32: correct
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:25): Sweet.  I am victorious.
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (21:26): notes that the topic goes double if people are going to try to reason about English
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:27): heh
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:27): "Please leave your sense of logic at the door, thanks!
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:31): Even without a sense of logic we can still apply reasoning rules mechanically
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:42): "Element h1 is not allowed in element body (note: schema is not yet completed)."  Heh.
